awd_titl_txt: Assessing Microstructural Damage Using Nonlinear Ultrasonics and Multiscale Numerical Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Ultrasonic testing uses high frequency sound waves to determine the state of materials without intrusion. The technique can be applied to flaw detection, small cracks due to fatigue, material characterization, and other applications. Nonlinear ultrasonic testing differs from its linear counterpart on the consideration of large amplitude of sound wave; therefore it has capabilities of detecting microstructural variations in aged steel. The measurable characteristics in nonlinear ultrasonic testing are influenced by various types and distribution of microstructural defects and cracks. This award supports fundamental research to understand the correlation between ultrasonic wave characteristics and microstructural damage. The research will develop a paradigm to detect damage in steel using ultrasonic waves by combining numerical modeling and experimental measurements. The research can be applied to structural health inspection of aging civil infrastructure such as truss bridges, pipelines, nuclear power plants, etc. Early detection of damage and subsequent repairs can extend life of structures. The results of this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. This research involves disciplines of computational mechanics, sensing and monitoring, and material science. The interdisciplinary approach will impact the education in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math disciplines.

Nonlinear ultrasonic testing detects microstructural variations through measuring high order harmonics; however, the nonlinear coefficient extracted from high order harmonics is influenced by the heterogeneous damage distribution and the various damage types. Although they can be assessed using experimental methods, it is practically infeasible to consider all variables in damage distribution and types when conducting nonlinear ultrasonic testing in situ. The research is to predict changes in the ultrasonic waves due to heterogeneous damage distribution in steel alloys using multi-scale numerical modeling and experiments. The micro-scale model containing material heterogeneity and microstructure will be created from micrographs to obtain nonlinear properties of damaged materials, which will then be utilized in macro scale models to assess damage. The multi-scale framework will allow modeling microstructural changes in the material and their effects on the behavior of the component. The changes in ultrasonic signal will be quantified and compared with changes in mechanical properties characterized via mechanical testing and microstructural analysis using other nondestructive evaluation techniques.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
1. The wavelet-based algorithms were developed to better extract higher harmonics in the ultrasonic testing. It was applied to investigating aluminum 1100 specimens subjected different levels of plastic deformations using nonlinear ultrasonic testing. The errors of harmonic decomposition of nonlinear wave signal were significantly reduced. Consequently, the obtained nonlinear acoustic parameters better correlate with plastic deformation levels.
  2. The developed methods were applied to detecting creep damage in 410 stainless steel specimens using nonlinear ultrasonic testing. The results show that the second harmonics were very weak, and did not exhibit noticeable correlation with the creep strain. In contrast, the third harmonic amplitude shows a good correlation with the creep strain.
  3. The sensitivity of the nonlinear ultrasonic testing is much higher than the linear velocity measurement in all three forms of damage investigated in this research, showing up to 150 times more change than the linear velocity does. However, the utilization of scanning acoustic microscope was found to be helpful along with the nonlinear testing in the determination of the localized damage for further testing.
  4. It was shown that the initial condition of the material, especially for the martensitic steels, can have a strong impact on the acoustic nonlinear parameter, and the initial annealed vs. hardened condition should be distinguished with appropriate references for further testing in the component to assess the remaining life.
  5. Several heterogeneous models were simulated with statistically variable heterogeneity characteristics and the correlation between these characteristics and higher harmonics were assessed. It was shown numerically that the third harmonic is an effective tool to detect damage in heterogeneous media, which was supported by experimental observations. Moreover, the standard deviation of material strength was shown to have the utmost significance compared to other heterogeneity properties like volume fraction and heterogeneity size in the generation of higher harmonics. In addition, the numerical study also showed that explicit modeling of heterogeneities once and only at the beginning of analysis, equips the simulation with sufficient information for undergoing any prescribed loading, hence monitoring the change in the model more efficiently.
  6. The numerical studies and predictions were crossly validated with nonlinear ultrasonic experiments and microscale imaging, including X-ray Diffraction (XRD) scanning. Numerical and experimental studies both indicated that non-uniform variations in different length scales affect the generation of both the second- and the third-harmonics and that both second- and third-harmonics acoustic nonlinearity parameters grow with the increase of plastic strain level. However, the third-harmonics acoustic nonlinearity parameter is more sensitive when micro-, meso-, and macrostructural variations exist. Accordingly, this parameter is a more potent indicator of nonlinearity in materials when nonuniform deformation is present.
  7. This research project continuously supported three Ph.D. students (two of them are female students). They have completed their Ph.D. degrees. The research activities during the project period provided the platform for students to share their ideas, develop critical thinking, develop presentation and communication skills, and interact with faculty/researchers with diverse backgrounds. The major research activities and results of the project result in three Ph.D. dissertations, 5 peer-reviewed journal papers, and 3 conference papers. One journal paper is under review (revised and resubmitted) and two are currently in preparation. In addition, the project supports the students and faculty to make presentations in major US conferences in different areas. Totally three conference presentations were made by the three Ph.D. students, and two were made by faculty. Two undergraduate students actively participated in the project. They both received the Chancellor?s Undergraduate Research Award of UIC (2016). In addition, one of them was an Honors College student, and her participation in research was important to achieve the Honors College responsibilities.
  8. The impact on the development of the related disciplines of the project includes:
  • The signal processing approach using wavelet transformation increases the accuracy of nonlinearity measurement in materials due to microstructural changes. The approach can be applied to various materials under different loading due to fatigue, creep, thermal etc. While the major focus of this research is on materials used in Civil Engineering applications, the knowledge and developed techniques can be extended to engineering materials used in other engineering disciplines.
  • The study on the experimental procedure of the water immersion ultrasound tests alongside with the development of superlattice brings the nonlinear ultrasound technique more close to being applied as an on-site nondestructive testing tool for premature failure of structures, e.g., nuclear power plants, pipelines, etc.
  • The developed harmonic-enriched numerical method can effectively model wave propagation and higher-order harmonics generation. This method and relevant numerical schemes developed may make an impact on modeling tools for high-frequency phenomena.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2019
Modified by: Sheng-Wei Chi
por.por_txt_cntn:
The wavelet-based algorithms were developed to better extract higher harmonics in the ultrasonic testing. It was applied to investigating aluminum 1100 specimens subjected different levels of plastic deformations using nonlinear ultrasonic testing. The errors of harmonic decomposition of nonlinear wave signal were significantly reduced. Consequently, the obtained nonlinear acoustic parameters better correlate with plastic deformation levels.
The developed methods were applied to detecting creep damage in 410 stainless steel specimens using nonlinear ultrasonic testing. The results show that the second harmonics were very weak, and did not exhibit noticeable correlation with the creep strain. In contrast, the third harmonic amplitude shows a good correlation with the creep strain. 
The sensitivity of the nonlinear ultrasonic testing is much higher than the linear velocity measurement in all three forms of damage investigated in this research, showing up to 150 times more change than the linear velocity does. However, the utilization of scanning acoustic microscope was found to be helpful along with the nonlinear testing in the determination of the localized damage for further testing.
It was shown that the initial condition of the material, especially for the martensitic steels, can have a strong impact on the acoustic nonlinear parameter, and the initial annealed vs. hardened condition should be distinguished with appropriate references for further testing in the component to assess the remaining life.
Several heterogeneous models were simulated with statistically variable heterogeneity characteristics and the correlation between these characteristics and higher harmonics were assessed. It was shown numerically that the third harmonic is an effective tool to detect damage in heterogeneous media, which was supported by experimental observations. Moreover, the standard deviation of material strength was shown to have the utmost significance compared to other heterogeneity properties like volume fraction and heterogeneity size in the generation of higher harmonics. In addition, the numerical study also showed that explicit modeling of heterogeneities once and only at the beginning of analysis, equips the simulation with sufficient information for undergoing any prescribed loading, hence monitoring the change in the model more efficiently.
The numerical studies and predictions were crossly validated with nonlinear ultrasonic experiments and microscale imaging, including X-ray Diffraction (XRD) scanning. Numerical and experimental studies both indicated that non-uniform variations in different length scales affect the generation of both the second- and the third-harmonics and that both second- and third-harmonics acoustic nonlinearity parameters grow with the increase of plastic strain level. However, the third-harmonics acoustic nonlinearity parameter is more sensitive when micro-, meso-, and macrostructural variations exist. Accordingly, this parameter is a more potent indicator of nonlinearity in materials when nonuniform deformation is present.
This research project continuously supported three Ph.D. students (two of them are female students). They have completed their Ph.D. degrees. The research activities during the project period provided the platform for students to share their ideas, develop critical thinking, develop presentation and communication skills, and interact with faculty/researchers with diverse backgrounds. The major research activities and results of the project result in three Ph.D. dissertations, 5 peer-reviewed journal papers, and 3 conference papers. One journal paper is under review (revised and resubmitted) and two are currently in preparation. In addition, the project supports the students and faculty to make presentations in major US conferences in different areas. Totally three conference presentations were made by the three Ph.D. students, and two were made by faculty. Two undergraduate students actively participated in the project. They both received the Chancellor?s Undergraduate Research Award of UIC (2016). In addition, one of them was an Honors College student, and her participation in research was important to achieve the Honors College responsibilities.
The impact on the development of the related disciplines of the project includes:
 

The signal processing approach using wavelet transformation increases the accuracy of nonlinearity measurement in materials due to microstructural changes. The approach can be applied to various materials under different loading due to fatigue, creep, thermal etc. While the major focus of this research is on materials used in Civil Engineering applications, the knowledge and developed techniques can be extended to engineering materials used in other engineering disciplines.
The study on the experimental procedure of the water immersion ultrasound tests alongside with the development of superlattice brings the nonlinear ultrasound technique more close to being applied as an on-site nondestructive testing tool for premature failure of structures, e.g., nuclear power plants, pipelines, etc.
The developed harmonic-enriched numerical method can effectively model wave propagation and higher-order harmonics generation. This method and relevant numerical schemes developed may make an impact on modeling tools for high-frequency phenomena.
